title: Debugger not working with web3, fails after Debugger.forTx call
body:
- [ ] I've [opened a support ticket](https://trufflesuite.zendesk.com/hc/en-us/requests/new) before filing this issue.

---------------------------

## Issue

I am trying to use the `@truffle/debugger` package with a web3 provider.

There is an error after calling `await Debugger.forTx(...)`

## Steps to Reproduce

```
import Web3 from "web3";
import Debugger from "@truffle/debugger";

let web3provider = new Web3.providers.HttpProvider("https://eth-mainnet.alchemyapi.io/v2/my_secret_key");
let web3 = new Web3(web3provider, null, {
	transactionConfirmationBlocks: 1,
});

let contracts = [... generated programatically ...];
let transactionHash = "0x03e784bfcb8f6175f7a321586f671dff08a87070f62f5c9ae928e8f2c31e17bd"; // randomly chosen from etherscan

// error happens during this function call:
let bugger = await Debugger.forTx(
	transactionHash,
	{
		provider: web3,
		contracts,
	},
);
```

## Expected Behavior

Debugging should not error.

## Actual Results

```
C:\Users\David\Documents\git\crypto-debug\backend\node_modules\.pnpm\web3-providers-http@1.7.0\node_modules\web3-providers-http\lib\index.js:86
    var request = this._prepareRequest();
                       ^
TypeError: this._prepareRequest is not a function
    at HttpProvider.send (C:\Users\David\Documents\git\crypto-debug\backend\node_modules\.pnpm\web3-providers-http@1.7.0\node_modules\web3-providers-http\lib\index.js:86:24)
    at node:internal/util:360:7
    at new Promise (<anonymous>)
    at promisify (node:internal/util:346:12)
    at xn.getTrace (C:\Users\leefaria\code\truffle\packages\debugger\lib\web3\adapter.js:13:24)
    at runCallEffect (C:\Users\David\Documents\git\crypto-debug\backend\node_modules\.pnpm\@redux-saga+core@1.1.3\node_modules\@redux-saga\core\dist\redux-saga-core.dev.cjs.js:528:21)
    at runEffect (C:\Users\David\Documents\git\crypto-debug\backend\node_modules\.pnpm\@redux-saga+core@1.1.3\node_modules\@redux-saga\core\dist\redux-saga-core.dev.cjs.js:1208:7)
    at digestEffect (C:\Users\David\Documents\git\crypto-debug\backend\node_modules\.pnpm\@redux-saga+core@1.1.3\node_modules\@redux-saga\core\dist\redux-saga-core.dev.cjs.js:1275:5)
    at next (C:\Users\David\Documents\git\crypto-debug\backend\node_modules\.pnpm\@redux-saga+core@1.1.3\node_modules\@redux-saga\core\dist\redux-saga-core.dev.cjs.js:1165:9)
    at proc (C:\Users\David\Documents\git\crypto-debug\backend\node_modules\.pnpm\@redux-saga+core@1.1.3\node_modules\@redux-saga\core\dist\redux-saga-core.dev.cjs.js:1112:3)
    at C:\Users\David\Documents\git\crypto-debug\backend\node_modules\.pnpm\@redux-saga+core@1.1.3\node_modules\@redux-saga\core\dist\redux-saga-core.dev.cjs.js:589:17
    at immediately (C:\Users\David\Documents\git\crypto-debug\backend\node_modules\.pnpm\@redux-saga+core@1.1.3\node_modules\@redux-saga\core\dist\redux-saga-core.dev.cjs.js:60:12)
    at runForkEffect (C:\Users\David\Documents\git\crypto-debug\backend\node_modules\.pnpm\@redux-saga+core@1.1.3\node_modules\@redux-saga\core\dist\redux-saga-core.dev.cjs.js:588:3)
    at runEffect (C:\Users\David\Documents\git\crypto-debug\backend\node_modules\.pnpm\@redux-saga+core@1.1.3\node_modules\@redux-saga\core\dist\redux-saga-core.dev.cjs.js:1208:7)
    at digestEffect (C:\Users\David\Documents\git\crypto-debug\backend\node_modules\.pnpm\@redux-saga+core@1.1.3\node_modules\@redux-saga\core\dist\redux-saga-core.dev.cjs.js:1275:5)
    at next (C:\Users\David\Documents\git\crypto-debug\backend\node_modules\.pnpm\@redux-saga+core@1.1.3\node_modules\@redux-saga\core\dist\redux-saga-core.dev.cjs.js:1165:9)
```

Although this error is originating from web3, I feel that this may be a problem with this package, since I don't generally get random web3 errors, and this package is supposed to work with web3.

## Environment

* Operating System: Windows 10
* Ethereum client: an alchemy rpc node
* Truffle version (`truffle version`): `"@truffle/debugger": "^9.2.12"`
* node version (`node --version`): `v17.2.0`
* npm version (`npm --version`): `8.1.4`

Yes, in web3.js, there's a difference between the `web3` object and the underlying provider.  (This is different from how Ethers works; it collapses this distinction.)  Rather than passing in `web3`, you should pass in `web3.currentProvider`.  Hopefully that should fix your problem.  Let us know if you have any further problems!

Thank you, that makes total sense.

However, I am now getting the following error:

```
TypeError: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'map')
    at Object.Abi (C:\Users\David\Documents\git\crypto-debug\backend\node_modules\.pnpm\@truffle+abi-utils@0.2.6\node_modules\@truffle\abi-utils\lib\normalize.ts:5:27)
```

I think I have everything right except one thing: I haven't been able to figure out what to put in for the `ast` for the contracts. So maybe this is what's causing the problem. Can you explain to me what `ast` should be? I can't find any documentation on it.

Well, you can see here that the problem is coming from `Abi` and `abi-utils`, so it's more likely that the problem is the omission of the ABIs, not the ASTs.  The debugger can function without the ASTs (though with much reduced functionality).  I suppose notionally it ought to be able to function without the ABIs as well, but missing ABIs are not a case that's ever come up before, so that's not something we ever bothered to make it robust against.

As for the ASTs, these are the abstract syntax trees that the Solidity compiler outputs.  If you're using Truffle, you can find them in the `ast` field in your Truffle artifacts.  If not, well, it's the `ast` output from solc.  You can read more [here](https://docs.soliditylang.org/en/v0.8.11/using-the-compiler.html#compiler-input-and-output-json-description) to see how to request it from solc and obtain it from the output.

Thank you again. This error is gone after adding the abi (which is missing from [the documentation](https://github.com/trufflesuite/truffle/tree/develop/packages/debugger)).

But now I am getting this problem:

```
    var request = this._prepareRequest();
                       ^
TypeError: this._prepareRequest is not a function
    at HttpProvider.send (C:\Users\David\Documents\git\crypto-debug\backend\node_modules\.pnpm\web3-providers-http@1.7.0\node_modules\web3-providers-http\lib\index.js:86:24)
```

Regarding the `ast`, I can't find any output from `solc` even after including it in the `outputSelection`. I'll try to use truffle for this instead.

> Thank you again. This error is gone after adding the abi (which is missing from the documentation).

Oh, wow, I didn't even realize we had that documentation.  Yeah, that's way out of date, sorry.  We haven't really been maintaining the debugger library documentation as so few people use it directly; sorry about that.

> Regarding the ast, I can't find any output from solc even after including it in the outputSelection. I'll try to use truffle for this instead.

Remember, the ast is per-source, not per-contract, so it has to go in the sources part of the outputSelection, not the contracts part.  As described there, you use `""` as the contract name to specify the per-source information to get.

> But now I am getting this problem:

Isn't that the same problem you reported originally?  I'm confused.

> Remember, the ast is per-source, not per-contract, so it has to go in the sources part of the outputSelection, not the contracts part. As described there, you use `""` as the contract name to specify the per-source information to get.

Sorry, I had it commented out the whole time ðŸ¤¦â€â™‚ï¸ I have the ast in place now.

> Isn't that the same problem you reported originally? I'm confused.

Yes... which is very confusing.

I just checked and the free node I am using does not support debugging, so maybe that's the problem. I'll see if I can get a node that supports debugging.

> I just checked and the free node I am using does not support debugging, so maybe that's the problem. I'll see if I can get a node that supports debugging.

That will indeed prevent the debugger from working, but it shouldn't lead to the particular problem you saw.  If you have more detailed reproduction steps I can try to reproduce this.

Note that if you want a node with debugging, you may be able to accomplish that by using Ganache to fork your node. :)  I'm not entirely clear on under what conditions that will or will not work, though.

OK, thanks, we'll take a look at this later!

> I actually was using Ganache's forking feature initially (after getting the email about it yesterday), but that was causing another error:

You should probably file an issue [on the Ganche repo](https://github.com/trufflesuite/ganache/issues), then!

OK, so, the good news is I've put up a PR to fix this problem as #4661.

The bad news is, if I'm not mistaken, that the endpoint you're using doesn't support `debug_traceTransaction`, so you're still going to get an error.  But, that's a different matter.  Hope this is helpful (once it's released)!

@haltman-at Thank you for everything! I'll try find a different endpoint :)

**Edit**: Great! I manually applied the patch and I'm no longer getting the `this._prepareRequest` error.
Great, glad it worked, thanks for bringing this problem to our attention!  Meanwhile the patch should go out officially later today. :)
This is addressed and released in [Truffle v5.4.31](https://github.com/trufflesuite/truffle/releases/tag/v5.4.31). Thanks!
